question: Which parameters influence capillary pressure according to the Young–Laplace equation? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Capillary pressure depends on surface tension, contact angle, and meniscus radius.
error: ❌ Capillary pressure does not depend on porosity but is influenced by interfacial properties and geometry.

question: What happens to capillary pressure when the pore radius decreases? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes! Smaller pores amplify capillary forces, increasing suction and retaining water more tightly.
error: ❌ Capillary pressure increases with decreasing pore size—this helps retain water in fine pores.

question: Which conditions favor upward capillary movement of water in soil? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Capillarity is strongest in fine pores with strong suction and good wetting conditions.
error: ❌ Upward movement is driven by capillary suction in unsaturated soils, not in fully saturated or non-wetting conditions.

question: Why can water remain suspended in soil after infiltration has stopped? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. Capillary and matric forces retain water even without flow.
error: ❌ Capillary suction and pore-scale forces—not positive pressure—allow water to remain held in soil.
